Once upon a time, Painkiller, Wolfenstein and Bioshock f*cked together and then Necrovision was born...It's nice shooter with old school vibe - bosses, big levels, lots of ammo, puzzles, switches, secret places, etc... The visuals are not top notch, but fits well. The cutscenes and voice acting are TERRIBLE, there are many bugs and glitches, but the game is actualy fun to play and thats where it shines - the gameplay.Nice mechanic is the use of melee combat (and shadohand on later stages), alongside with the pistol. Once the player get the shadowhand, the gameplay is becoming closer to the Bioshock series, cause the different spells, combined with the tipical gun shooting. Controls are little different compared to the Bioshock though - left mouse button for the left hand, right mouse button for the right hand.I said "combined", so now is the time to mention the COMBOOOS.Our hero have three types of melee attacks - kick, left hand melee and gun melee attack. The bayonettas and the shovels can be thrown at the enemies to nail them on the wall, the gas lamps exept to light the way, can be used to burn the hordes of undeads and freaky creatures. The arsenal is impressive.It's good to perform different attacks to create combo. For example - knock down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the ground and then finish him out with the pump. Or slice him with the bayonetta for the "Herr Doktor" combo.There are different "challenge rooms", which becomes avalible after beating any given level. The challenge rooms helps the player to permanently unlock different gear types to be avalible in the inventory.There are parts of the game when the player controls giant mech or even ride a dragon. Yeah, the it's total mashup of many mechanics from different games (there is even bullet time system implemented in it), but it fun to play and it works...for the most of the time.It's not AAA title, it screams "I'M A CHEAP, LOW BUDGET, SOMETIMES UGLY GAME", but it's charming in some inexplicable way. So, try it!7/10

												Necrovision is a strange game. Stuck between a myriad of styles and influences, it emerges as a blend between the atmosphere of classic world war shooters and the crazy mass murder party of games such as Painkiller, Serious Sam or Bulletstorm. The overall result is highly personal and depends heavily on your mindset: don't go into this game expecting an AAA shooter. You'll find cringeworthy cutscenes, amateurish voice acting, a pixelated GUI and weird bugs all around.However, as soon as you get past its imperfections, you'll be playing a pretty crazy and fun game with a (surprisingly!) relatively readable storyline, zombie beheading, dragons, huge boss fights and lots of other nonsense♥♥♥♥♥♥happening in WWI. One of the biggest surprises was level design, which, although relatively linear, is huge, well planned enough, often aesthetically pleasing and with a very classic feel and pace.On less positive points, the combo system is pretty bland and doesn't really feel well-implemented (although it can be fun). The weapons are also sub-par: the historical limitations are understandable, but for a game this crazy, they often slow the action to a crawl as you painstakingly bolt your rifle after every shot fighting giant demon things. Health is also a bit weird: medkits exist and are pretty abundant but are close to useless since your health automatically recharges up to about 75%; which breaks some of the classic appeal in my view.Overally, Necrovision is a pretty fun experience if you're willing to forget its technical shortcomings and accept its particular brand of insanity. 7.5/10

On one point the game is awesome and briliant that you want to shout out: 'PEOPLE PLAY THIS GAME IT IS AWESOME!' and at the same time there are things about this game that are utterly garbage and stupid that make you wanna scream warnings: 'STAY AWAY FROM THIS'This game is hard to get into and easy to bounce off and never try it again. The overal shooting is really difficuly to adjut but once you start to 'feel' the game more you start to get much more fun from it and that is where I am right now and that is  why despite all the flaws and problems this game has, I must put my thumb up as I found what I came here for, it wasnt pretty and painless but in the end satisfining.I wish they could create a remake of this game where they polish and improve the bad things. 												One of the wierdest shooters I've ever played. If I had to describe it as briefly as possible I'd say it's DooM set during WWI, with some LOTR mixed in because kraut zombies wasn't strange enough. The first half of the game is a relatively standard period shooter with bullet-sponge opponents; These levels are well designed but drag on a bit. The second half of Necrovision is where things start to shine, as you find yourself dropped into the middle of a compelling underground fantasy realm populated by imaginative (and truly chilling) monsters like gas-mask spiders, flamethrower rat-men, ninja vampires, angry spirits and yes, DRAGONS. The needlessly convoluted story concerns the subjugation of this under-world by demonic forces, who are now spilling over onto the surface. It is here you receive an entirely new set of weapons and a nifty melee super-gauntlet that can be charged with the souls of fallen enemies to unleash powerful explosive attacks. I wish some of the opening missions could be shortened or cut completely to make way for this part of the game, as no doubt many players will be turned off by their first-impression of Necrovision before having a chance to experience the good stuff.Technically the game is rough around the edges, with some maddening difficulty spikes, but worth it for shooter enthusiasts in search of an original premise and oppressive atmosphere.

												Necrovision - one of *those* games that would really worth to be remade from the very basics, because besides of it's ideas it's filled to the brim with terrible choices and implementations. Hitbox, view, weapons, protagonist style, enemy attacks, sounds - so many thing could be improved. Do you really want to play it? Play it. Are you curious if it's generally worth playing? The answer is a really, really solid no.TLDR about mechanics: weapon selection is unreliable, headbob is super nauseating and actively prevents gameplay, level and enemy design is boring + last levels is artifically hard with deadly pitfalls and HORDES or knockback enemies. These make the game an unfair chore instead of a fun, or challenging shooter. The story... let's say it's unique. WW1 happens, then zombies, wraiths, trolls (?)...  a dragon appears, later you defeat mandatory evil german scientist's giant scorpion tank with your walking tank (yes.), only to later realize the vampires, living underground are corrupted by the demons whom Zimmermann allowed into the world, so you have to fight machinegun-wielding vampires, later ratmen equipped iwth flamethrowers while throwing fireballs and stakes out of your magical weapon, only to fight Satan in hell after taking a flying trip with a dragon. YES. THIS IS THE STORY.  I don't know what they were tripping on, but let's just ignore this....Let's say the ideas are okay. But then I'm still left with a game where I can have 6 items cycling on my key 1, later I have magics on 1 (really bad idea, only forward cycling) AND my one-armed guns, and I have to cycle all 4 with my mouse wheel. Meanwhile keys 6-9 are not even used. What the hell....  and if weapon changing troubles wouldn't be enough, there are a lot of melee enemies who attack by dashing "through" you, as they constantly clip though you. They shriek, they sometimes not even visible because they are IN you, and you are also experiencing the worst headbob I've ever seen. Using submachine gun in iron sights is a trip for seizure-land, and even just ogres being around means a MASSIVE shaking effect that means useless aiming. And as you fight mostly undeads, headshots are a nice way to kill, otherwise it takes 3-5 times more shots. Now if you add this info together that they can stunlock you because you can't aim...  Then on the final levels when you can even fall down into lava they introduce enemies that jump at you, knocking you back super-hard (while using a stock sound asset), because there are no way to make those levels be more hated than that. If not for the bet/promise that I will finish the game, I would have stopped around chapter 2-3 out of 12...it would have been a definitely better decision.

												Quick Summary: Action / Horror First Person Shooter with mostly World War 1 weapons, though that changes about half way through the game. The graphics are decent for an indie game and gameplay is pretty basic shooting with partially regenerating health so you can run through large portions of the game.You play Simon, an American soldier in Europe fighting the Germans in World War 1, but you quickly encounter far more dangerous enemies as the dead rise and demonic forces appear out of thin air. As you sacrifice your humanity and progress deeper and deeper underground, you find the ancient world of the vampires, who look like people in heavy bug armor (watch out for their vampire kung fu). For ages the vampires have held back the demons from invading, and now it’s up to Simon to do what they no longer can: Enter the portal to Hell and defeat the demon lords.Right from the start of the game you’ll get some pretty pathetic World War 1 guns and throwable weapons. Most of the enemies in the game have enough life that it takes a few seconds of shooting to kill them. That means any more than 3 or 4 enemies at once can be a threat to you, especially when you run into the big dudes who actually run faster than you and take about 5 clips of ammo to kill. Like a lot of modern games, if you can avoid taking damage for a few seconds, your life will partially regenerate (up to about 60%). This means you can run past about half the enemies in the game (much harder in later levels with teleporting enemies). An additional tool in your bag of tricks is the “adrenaline” meter which you charge up by killing enemies. The adrenaline can be used to temporarily slow down time, making it easier to avoid enemy attacks (or run away like me). If you take enough damage to kill you, and you have a full adrenaline meter, the time slow will activate automatically and you’ll actually become invincible during the effect. Unfortunately, during the time slow, your attacking and reloading is slowed down too, so don’t think you can just use the opportunity to blast everyone. Additionally, when you’ve started your descent underground you’ll acquire a special weapon with magical attacks (shadowhand). It’s not as cool as it sounds, but it adds to your arsenal.Pros:+I enjoy horror shooters (like Jericho) and despite having mixed ratings, the story is ok.+This is a straightforward run and gun. There isn’t that much puzzle solving so if you just want to blast some enemies, you can do that. You have a little compass on your HUD that points you which direction you need to go.Cons:-The game crashes occasionally for no apparent reason. Also, I wasn’t able to Alt+Tab out of the game without the game freezing. There’s a bug causing blurry vision, but that can be fixed with a command line addition.-The little cut scenes between levels are weird. Not only is the subtitling occasionally wrong, but they show and say things that don’t make much sense relative to what has happened in the gameplay. This is likely due to the game’s developers not being native English speakers.Overall, the game is a mostly brainless shooter and if you’ve played the Serious Sam or Painkiller games, you should have an idea what to expect. The game isn’t awesome, but it’s not completely horrible either. 6/10

												This game is quite literally the best thing ever. In spite of the overwhelming glitches, bad graphics (which also glitch) and extremely cheesy plot and dialogue, the game is extremely fun to play. Especially if you try to get good at it. In it´s surface, Necrovision is just a shooter, but actually, it is much more than that. It´s a shooter alright, but also a rhythm game, due to the way reloading can be sped up (which is crutial on higher difficulties) a bit of a mystery with the strange story-line, but most importantly: a complete mayhem. Let me illustrate just how much of a mayhem this game is: assuming you collect a sufficient amount of Bonus Items, you gain some pretty crazy special abilities, that mix quite well with the magic you learn to use half way through the game (spoilers!)  one of those literally turns everybody around you into burning statues. You will watch the attacking enemies petrify and incinerate mid-swing while laughing skulls burst out of your infernal aura and pierce your enemies and your death-claw relentlesly unleashes one fireball after another...! No other game can do this.Not only does Necrovision approach degrees of mayhem never before seen in another game, but its gunplay is rock solid. You get to dual wield everything, you can use melee weapons with ranged weapons at the same time, you can beat people up with a pistol (for bonus points!) there are many ways to approach the game. I ofter found myself returning to the earlier levels just to shoot people in the head with my trusty luger (which is absolutely brutal when comboed with rhythmical  reload acceleration) but those are unfortunately quite few.The chief problems of this game is the lack of levels. It´s just too darn short for such a niche role. There is no other game that can satisfy one´s desire for destruction like this one, but to quench it 100%, it´s just too short (meaning, it´s got only a normal length campain, a bunch of challenges, and nothing more - no multiplayer of any sort) Due to this, I give this game a 8/10. Meaning it´s about 4 times better than Bioshock Infinite !GASP! which makes it a must buy. Make your mum proud of your Wampire World War achievements.

There are also times he will talk with what sounds like a demonic version of Caleb from the 1990s 3dgore shooter BLOOD by MONOLITH after alot of carnage and going into a murderous rage. Music is grand and epic with some very powerful fitting classical atmosphere. Alot of the environments are destructable with different ways of making them into shattered wreckage. 												Necrovision não é nenhuma maravilha mas tá longe de ser um fps ruim. Tem gráficos interessantes e imersivos em diversos momentos e músicas boas mas que depois de um tempo começam a ficar repetitivas, por isso não brilham tanto. A proposta do jogo é enfocar mais no combate do que na história, por isso as vzes tem umas coisas sem pé nem cabeça, assim como  zumbis e soldados que desmembramos a todo momento na engine de física divertida. O arsenal de armas vai desde tipos de pistolinhas, metralhadoras, snipers, baioneta, shotgun, até um canhão lá antigo e armas melle como espadas e pás também. É gostoso decapitar cabeças e desmembrar corpos dos zumbis e soldados  com essas armas todas. A história se passa na Guerra Mundial e o que começa numa guerra comum passa a desvendar uma maldição de mortos se reanimando. Zumbis variados, alguns que rastejam, e os soldados alemães vivos também continuam na brincadeira, e mais adiante começam a aparecer até ogros gigantes e demônios alados e também seres que mais aparecem alienígenas. Aparece até um dragão! Mas e sse ajuda a gente. A gente "pilota" o dragão. O jogo é uma loucura do começo ao fim por isso não dá pra levar tão a sério, e sim viajar com ele, surfar na idéia louca do desenvolvedor. O foco do jogo não é ter a história redondinha, e sim maluquinha. Num esquema de jogo que lembra Serious Sam e Painkiller. Bem jogável o jogo e recomendo bastante. Fechei o jogo no modo demonscrusher. O jogo tem artefatos pra achar pra aprimorar alguns combos.

Soldier comes running at you, soldier gets killed by incredibly badass looking enemy, you awkwardly run up to the enemy, you do this awkward punch like thing, one punch later the incredibly badass enemy turns into a rag-doll, your plastic face looks into the camera.They obviously tried to emulate Painkiller by making both you and the enemies move incredibly fast, which would have helped normally with the gunplay, except you are constantly packed into tight corridors where you are consistently bumping into things, trying to pick out the gray-brown enemies from the gray-brown environment.
